title: Meet Pranjal Patil, India’s First Visually-Challenged Woman IAS Officer
text:
The Union Public Service Commission (UPSC) is regarded among the toughest examinations to crack and hundreds of thousands of aspirants flock coaching centres in major metropolitan cities across the country in the hope to join the IAS, IPS and IFS ranks.

Thiruvananthapuram's new sub collector- Pranjal Patil. India's 1st visually impaired IAS officer. "Don't give up.Keep trying. You will get that one break that you require", says Pranjal Patil.She was refused joining by IRAS, but is today a sub-collector! @ndtv pic.twitter.com/3Q22bCVt3x — Sneha Koshy (@SnehaMKoshy) October 14, 2019

And the journey was more tedious for Pranjil Patil, who has become the country’s first visually-challenged woman IAS officer.

"Never be defeated, Never give up,'' she said as she assumed charge as the Sub Collector of Thiruvananthapuram, the capital of Kerala, on October 14.

Kerala: Pranjal Patil, India’s first visually challenged woman IAS officer takes charge as Sub Collector of Thiruvananthapuram. pic.twitter.com/opUn08uu6X — ANI (@ANI) October 14, 2019

Don't Miss 363 SHARES 9.4 K SHARES 13.7 K SHARES 6.2 K SHARES 3.5 K SHARES

Patil, who hails from Ulhasnagar in Maharashtra, had lost her vision when she was just six years old.

She cracked the Union Public Service Commission (UPSC) examination in 2016 and secured 773rd rank and improved her ranking to 124 the next year.

Patil was appointed Ernakulam Assistant Collector during her training period.

She insisted that we should “never be defeated and we should never give up” because with our efforts all of us will get that one breakthrough which we want.

Thiruvananthapuram's new sub collector- Pranjal Patil. India's 1st visually impaired IAS officer. "Don't give up.Keep trying. You will get that one break that you require", says Pranjal Patil.She was refused joining by IRAS, but is today a sub-collector! pic.twitter.com/Fz82m5uIvk — keshaboina sridhar (@keshaboinasri) October 14, 2019

The 30-year old Kerala cadre officer has set an example for all of us to follow but her rise to prominence is replete with determination and courage in the face of adversity.

A warm reception was arranged to welcome her as she took over from former collector B Gopalakrishnan.

"I am feeling extremely glad and proud after taking this charge. As I start working, I will be able to know more about the district and would plan better for it. I expect support and cooperation from my fellow members and people of Trivandrum," Patil said while speaking to the media.

Despite losing eyesight at a young age, she did not lose hope and completed her graduation in political science with a master's in International relations from Jawaharlal Nehru University.

Patil was ranked 733 in civil services in her first attempt in 2016 and 124 next year.

With Inputs From Agencies
